title: Maria Shriver believes cell phones are causing 'mental health problems'
text:
She believes cell phones are causing 'real mental health problems.'

And Maria Shriver explained the reasons why to CNN on Friday saying: 'it's due to our lack of connection.'

Talking face to face 'makes me feel understood, makes me feel I’m looking at someone and I’m finding common ground,' she said. 'I’m hearing them, I’m listening to how they got to where they are.'

Tough call: Maria Shriver believes that cell phones are causing a societal disconnect; seen in May at SXSW

The journalist, 63, added: 'I get in an elevator and people don’t even look up.

'There’s no denying that is all coinciding with these epidemics of anxiety and loneliness across generations. We’re technically connected, but we’re not connected.

'Loneliness, anxiety, depression, trauma, all these things, I think, is coming from the lack of talking.'

Maria revealed that she won't let anyone keep their phones when they have dinner with her.

Honest approach: Talking face to face 'makes me feel understood, makes me feel I’m looking at someone and I’m finding common ground,' she said. 'I’m hearing them, I’m listening to how they got to where they are'

No phones! Maria Shriver's daughter Christine holds her cell phone in her hand after lunch with her mom in August. Maria believes the devices contribute to the 'epidemics of anxiety and loneliness across generations. We’re technically connected, but we’re not connected'

She shares children Katherine, 29, Christina, 28, Patrick, 25, and Christopher, 21, with ex-husband Arnold Schwarzenegger, 72. And the phone ban extends to Katherine's new husband, Chris Pratt, 40.

'They know when they come for Sunday dinner, they don’t have the phone,' she said. 'It’s down in the kitchen. And if I see it, I say "phone" and they put it away. There’s no substitute for the human connection.'

Meanwhile, Maria has spent the week appearing on NBC's Hoda & Jenna and on Friday she posted a gushing thank you to Hoda Kotb, 55.

Love the look: Maria spent the week appearing on NBC's Hoda & Jenna and on Friday she posted a gushing thank you to Hoda Kotb, 55, and a shout out to the hair stylists on Instagram

'My friendship with her brings me so much joy. I feel loved, seen, accepted. It’s a gift. She’s unbelievable — generous and loving,' she said.

'I also need to add a big thank you to all the producers and the hair & makeup team that helped me all week!

'I’ve gotten so many compliments on my hair especially, so I’m going into weekend feeling loved! Thank you!'
description: The 63-year-old journalist, activist and mom-of-four said Friday she believes many people suffering with loneliness, anxiety, depression, trauma are doing so because of a 'lack of human connection,'
